Award.AwardTitle: OP: Building Artificial Photonic Materials from Nanoscale Optical Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: Photonic materials are patterned constructs consisting of particles, smaller than the wavelength of light, that are artificially bound together in various ordered arrangements. By varying the size, shape and periodic arrangement of the particles it is possible to control material optical properties such as color, shine and even the absorption of light. This project aims to design and build photonic materials comprising particles that are only a few nanometers in size. This is accomplished by shining light onto a fluid containing numerous metal nanoparticles. Analogous to the process of atoms joining to form molecules, the metal nanoparticles bind together in the fluid to form arrangements of particles. By varying the flow of the fluid it is possible to control the structure of these photonic materials, and therefore their optical properties. A combination of computer simulations and experiments provide a rich environment for training undergraduate and graduate students. Incorporating components of the research into existing undergraduate courses and laboratory experiments enables students to develop a deeper understanding of a wide range of materials-related concepts.

Technical description: Optical matter represents a unique material arising from pure mesoscale electrodynamic interactions of colloidal particles in an optical field. Due to significant instabilities associated with nanoparticle-comprising optical matter, previous studies have predominately addressed microparticle-based structures. This project aims to eliminate the inherent instability problem and create a paradigm for constructing artificial photonic materials using nanoscale optical matter. The paradigm relies on advanced laser beam shaping techniques and significant mesoscale electrodynamic interactions among strongly scattering plasmonic metal nanoparticles in optical fields. Efficient simulation models are developed to elucidate the collective electrodynamic interactions of multiple nanoparticles, to reveal the equilibrium binding configurations. Optimized optical fields are created to increase the spatial and temporal stability of the nanoscale optical matter. Optical-matter-embedded polymer microparticles are further fabricated in microfluidic channels by photopolymerization. These hybrid particles can serve as building blocks for two- or three-dimensional metal-dielectric superlattices, leading to new types of photonic materials with tailored optical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research on light-induced self-assembly of nanoparticles in this project has added a new tool to nanotechnology. Assembly of nanoparticles into precisely ordered structures is an essential pursuit of nanotechnology, yet classical optical tweezers can only trap single particles in tightly focused laser beams where multiple trapped particles tend to aggregate. Interparticle optical binding interactions offer a unique approach to assemble multiple particles by light, but previously this phenomenon was only observed for dielectric microparticles. The PI?s research on optical binding of metal nanoparticles in the project, both experimental and computational, has laid the foundation for creating large-scale artificial photonic materials with novel structures in designed optical fields.

Computationally, the PI invented a coupled Finite-difference time-domain (FDTD)/particle dynamics method, which can dynamically calculate the mutual interactions of multiple nanoparticles in optical fields and predict their self-assembled structures (J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2018, 9, 545). This method can predict the stable configurations of optical matter as well as the trajectories that the nanoparticles take to get to those configurations. This method can also accurately calculate the angular velocity of rotating optical matter, which agreed very well with the experimental observations (Nat. Commun. 2018, 9, 4897). This method further allows designing optical sorting strategies by simulating the motion of single nanoparticles in optical line traps (Nano Lett., 2018, 18, 4500) and in optofluidic potential wells (Nano Lett. 2018, 18, 7400).

Experimentally, through a series of innovative experiments, the PI demonstrated that the stability of nanoscale optical matter can be controlled by tuning the intensity and polarization of the incident laser beam. In Nano Lett. 18, 1396-1401 (2018), the PI introduced a new way to probe the stability of optical matter chains self-organized by Au nanoparticles in optical line traps. In Adv. Funct. Mater., 29, 1808258 (2019), the PI invented a new method to create a lateral interferometric optical field by illuminating a single Ag nanowire drop-casted on a coverslip, which can enhance both optical trapping and binding of nanoparticles near the nanowire. This work was selected as a cover image of the journal Advanced Functional Materials. The PI further improved this approach by using a free-standing nanoparticle chain with a tunable length as the laser beam shaper (Nano Lett. 2019, 19, 3353). Moreover, the PI revealed several novel properties of optical matter structures, including negative optical torque (Nat. Commun. 2018, 9, 4897), self-replication (Adv. Mater. 2018, 30, 1803238), self-healing (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2019, 58, 4917), and self-stabilization (ACS Nano 2020, 14, 6616). In particular, the stable negative optical torque is the first observation without resorting to birefringent materials or inhomogeneous media.

In addition, the PI has invented new optical nanomanipualtion methods. Very recently, the PI revealed that the synergy of intensity, phase, and polarization in structured light can generate tunable optical forces on nanostructures (Nano Lett. 2020, 20, 2778). The PI has thus created new beam shaping methods to simultaneously control these optical parameters, and further invented an automatic optical manipulation apparatus with a new class of reconfigurable optical traps (ACS Nano 2020, 14, 7602). These traps can provide integrated optical transporting and trapping functions, allowing optical sorting at the single-particle level with single-nanometer precision. These studies largely enrich the toolbox of optical tweezers that traditionally only rely on intensity gradient and provide new research opportunities in nanophotonics and biology.  

The investigation funded by this award has generated thirteen publications, nearly all in high-impact journals. The results were also presented in conferences, including invited talks at the CLEO Conference, OSA Advanced Photonics Congress, SPIE Nanoscience + Engineering conference, ACS Fall National Meeting, and Gordon Conference. The research project has provided opportunities to train three undergraduates (one female), two graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher. Of particular note, the first author of one publication was an undergraduate student. Moreover, the PI has built a classical optical tweezers setup for a nanophotonics course at UNC Chapel Hill, which improved the infrastructure for undergraduate education. The project also facilitated the collaboration of the PI with industry on possible applications of photonic materials based on optical matter via an NSF IUCRC center (Center for Metamaterials).
